Award.AwardTitle: Electromagnetic Shields Based on MXene Nano-Metamaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
All modern electronics uses electromagnetic shields to cut down on electrical interferences that can completely destroy information stored and passed by the electronic components. This is particularly important in military applications, medical electronics and consumer wireless systems including wearable devices and 5G cell phones. The present day electromagnetic shielding technology is challenged to keep up with the need for being lighter and smaller. Conventional metal shields commonly used today are bulky and lack mechanical flexibility. The proposed work focuses on developing new highly effective electromagnetic shields of dramatically reduced weight and size. They will be thinner than sheets of paper and completely flexible. This new technology is based on the recently discovered new class of materials called MXenes. The proposal will develop MXene electromagnetic shields that can be laid over flexible electronics and even spray painted over it. We will learn how to optimize shielding behavior of these novel materials and develop software and models to help creators of modern electronics to design the most effective electromagnetic shields.

While previous work demonstrated that MXene layers thinner than typical copper shields are capable of shielding electromagnetic fields in the RF and microwave region just as well, there has been no clear explanation for the reasons behind such outstanding performance. Yet, understanding is critical to developing thinner, lighter and more flexible shielding devices. Preliminary measurements indicate that MXene, despite having conductivity lower than copper, has an anomalously high effective dielectric constant. This seems to result in the material characteristic impedance low enough to explain MXeneâ€™s great shielding performance. It is known that high dielectric constant can be obtained in artificially created conducting structures known as meta-materials. We conjecture that MXene has certain micro-structural features that, although somewhat random, result in meta-material-like behavior. To develop a much better understanding of this behavior and to design more effective shields, the proposed work will combine analytical and numerical electromagnetic modeling and simulations with fabrication of MXene shielding devices and their experimental testing. Modeling and simulation work will focus on quasi-periodic micro-structure of MXenes in order to determine the circumstances under which these materials would have high effective dielectric constant combined with high effective conductivity. Candidate MXene structures most likely to yield best shields will be fabricated into sheets and filler epoxy-based shields and tested using waveguides and near-field measurements. Modeling and simulation results will be compared with the experimental measurements for model validation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The advancement in recent technologies involve electronic components are very sensitive to external electromagnetic waves. Electromagnetic interference (EMI) can disrupt the normal operation of devices like sensors, circuits, and processors, leading to poor performance. EMI shielding helps prevent such disruptions, ensuring that such devices operate effectively. Our project investigates the properties that make titanium carbide (Ti3C2) MXene an effective EMI shielding material. These properties include the metallic behavior for ultrathin films, and interlayer spacing between the MXene flakes on the nanoscale.

The study on “Ultrathin MXene film interaction with electromagnetic radiation in the microwave range" presents several key results related to the electromagnetic interference (EMI) shielding performance of Ti3C2 MXene films. Ultrathin MXene films, as thin as 4 nm, were able to absorb up to 50% of electromagnetic wave in the X-band (8.2–12.4 GHz) due to impedance matching with the wave propagation medium. As the thickness increased, absorption decreased, and reflection became dominant due to the increase in sheet conductivity.

In addition, the films exhibited high conductivity, with values around 106 S/m, comparable to ultrathin metal films like gold. The sheet impedance and conductivity values were consistent across both DC and microwave frequencies, implying the same charge transport mechanism from DC to GHz range. As the thickness of the films increased, their shielding effectiveness also increased as reflection became the main mode of EMI shielding. This reflects the dominance of reflective properties over absorption in thicker MXene films.

The other study on the “Influence of MXene Interlayer Spacing on the Interaction with Microwave Radiation" explores how variations in the interlayer spacing of Ti3C2 MXene films impact their interaction with electromagnetic wave. Films with interlayer spacing between 1.9 Å and 5.5 Å were made by using different intercalating agents each with a different size. 

The films exhibited a wide range of DC conductivities that decreased exponentially with increasing interlayer spacing. This confirmed that even with increased interlayer spacing, the films can maintain substantial microwave absorption. Meanwhile, UV-vis spectroscopy revealed that the optical absorbance of the films decreases as the interlayer spacing increases, reflecting lower electron transport efficiency across flakes.

The studies demonstrated that ultrathin Ti3C2 films display shielding effectiveness compared to ultrathin gold films, with the added advantages of being more abundant, easier to process, and tunable for specific applications. In addition, we’ve shown that MXene interlayer spacing plays a crucial role in controlling electromagnetic properties, with potential applications in electromagnetic absorbers and reflectors. By tuning the interlayer spacing, MXene films can achieve highly absorptive or reflective behavior in the microwave range, making them suitable for a range of electronic applications.
